Homotopy vs strict colimits

Jul 26, 2019

Yesterday, at the lecture series, Peter May gave a wild and incredibly entertaining lecture (to an audience which hadn’t necessarily seen a ton of algebraic topology): he defined what a cohomology theory is via axioms, then defined -spectra, defined ordinary homology via Eilenberg-Maclane spaces (he’d already done the classifying space construction), wrote down (and sang!) Bott periodicity, and defined homology and the Hurewicz image for connected spaces via the Dold-Thom theorem. This final topic got me thinking: since , can we model as a homotopy colimit rather than a strict categorical colimit (as it is usually defined)? I then found this MathOverflow question, and I figured I’d state the results in some generality. As mentioned in that MathOverflow question, this book contains the details of constructing the symmetric product in spaces as a homotopy colimit.

We’ll begin by reviewing what’s already in the MathOverflow post. We’d first like to be able to build as a homotopy colimit, and then somehow go to . First, note that is a space with a -action, so defines a functor . We can right Kan extend along the inclusion , and this defines a functor — it’s the usual thing one does to view a naive -object as a genuine -object. Then , and the strict colimit of is (if a subgroup of identifies points, then, well, so does the entire group!). Of course, this argument generalizes to any topological group and replaced by any space with a -action. Now, Dror-Farjoun shows in Lemma 4.A.3 of his book that the map from (in pointed spaces) to is a homotopy equivalence, because is a “free diagram”, and so .

It’s sort of evident that one should expect this sort of result to be true in some level of generality. Let be a monoidal model category. For any -enriched category (like ), we should be able to construct an orbit category such that for any functor , where is an -enriched cofibrantly generated model category, equipped with a set of generating cofibrations (we’re supposed to have with the Quillen model structure (so ) in mind), there is an induced functor whose strict colimit is the homotopy colimit of . This ultimately boils down to cellular approximation.

This is just a matter of adopting definitions to this generalized situation; it’s nothing new. Define to be the category of functors whose strict categorical colimit is . Define for each an object of by a functor sending to . Define a new collection of maps in as follows: a natural transformation between functors is in if and only if is of the form for some , where . We would like to be a set, so we need to assume that is a small category. A free cellular -diagram in is defined to be an -cell complex in , i.e., an object such that the map from the initial object to can be constructed as a transfinite composition of pushouts of elements of .

Then, for every diagram , we can, by cellular approximation in the projective model structure on (Proposition 11.2.7 here) find a free diagram with a natural weak equivalence , such that the natural map is a weak equivalence. This final property follows from the fact that is projectively cofibrant. Equivalently, the above discussion can be phrased as saying that we have defined for each as above a “free” functor whose strict colimit is the homotopy colimit of . This free replacement is generally rather different from at the point-set level, though.

This is highly suggestive of a more general, abstract, setup of equivariant homotopy theory. Maybe this is related to the Clark Barwick school’s approach to equivariant homotopy theory?
